body:
Hi German,


in those cases, we usually use "Meteonorm" to generate a specific weather data set. It  interpolates from the closest weather stations and they have a huge data basis. For Chile I would guess around 20 (just rough estimation looking at the map).
But it is important to know that the hourly irradiation data is generated stochastically from the monthly data (from the weather stations), so Meteonorm does not use hourly measured data as basis.


So in some kind you get a artificial weather data set, based on the interpolation of real measurements.
It includes also temperature and humidity, all you need for thermal simulation, too.


The output can be chosen in different formats, also epw.


cheers,


Jan
